title: Israel-Iran live updates: Officials assess damage from U.S. strikes on Iran, as Trump raises possibility of regime change
description: Trump said the U.S. hit the Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan nuclear sites. Iran’s foreign minister called it a “dangerous military operation” against his country.
author: Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Leo Sands, Abbie Cheeseman, Sammy Westfall, Joshua Yang
byline: Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Leo Sands, Abbie Cheeseman, Sammy Westfall, Joshua Yang, Hannah Knowles, Cat Zakrzewski, Clara Ence Morse, Natalie Allison, Michael Birnbaum, Kyle Melnick, Meg Kelly, Joyce Sohyun Lee, Nilo Tabrizy, Evan Hill, Dylan Moriarty, Karen DeYoung, Lior Soroka, Susannah George, Yeganeh Torbati, Dan Lamothe, Mariana Alfaro, Theodoric Meyer, Azi Paybarah, Erin Cunningham, Karla Adam, Alon Rom, Alex Horton, Maham Javaid, Warren P. Strobel, Supriya Kumar, Claire Parker, Mohamad El Chamaa, Heidi Levine, Naomi Schanen, Ellen Francis, Kate Brady, Suzan Haidamous, Jonathan Baran, Amaya Verde, Álvaro Valiño, N. Kirkpatrick
excerpt: Trump said the U.S. hit the Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan nuclear sites. Iran’s foreign minister called it a “dangerous military operation” against his country.
text: President Donald Trump suggested the possibility of regime change in Iran, after his top officials said the administration wasn’t interested in such a move. On social media, he posted that “if the current Iranian Regime is unable to MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN, why wouldn’t there be a Regime change?” The U.N. Security Council held an emergency meeting called by Iran to address the U.S. strikes on its nuclear facilities. International Atomic Energy Agency officials are still assessing the extent of the damage. Iran’s permanent representative to the United Nations described the U.S. strikes as a “blatant crime” and accused Israel of drawing Trump into the conflict, adding that Iran’s armed forces will decide the “timing, nature, and scale of Iran’s proportionate response.” What else to know after the U.S. attacksReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump said U.S. warplanes carried out a “very successful attack” on three Iranian sites, including the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility, which is hundreds of feet below ground. He did not cite evidence regarding the strikes’ impact. All three facilities sustained “extremely severe damage and destruction,” said Chairman of the Joints Chief of Staff Dan Caine, citing initial damage assessments. Israeli military spokesman Effie Defrin said Sunday that the strikes were carried out in full coordination with the Israel Defense Forces, without giving any further details.Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities in the “strongest terms” on Sunday, accusing Washington of betraying diplomatic efforts and asserting that Iran reserved “all options” to act in self-defense.Israel and Iran traded fire for a 10th day Sunday as the Israeli defense minister said the country’s military “will continue operations until the objectives of the operation are achieved.” Iranian missiles penetrated Israeli air defenses and struck buildings in central Israel during two volleys of attacks, the IDF said. Iranian state media reported deaths and injuries from Israeli airstrikes on Iran on Sunday, while the IDF said it struck military targets in multiple regions across Iran.Live coverage contributors 43Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces gave the all-clear, telling residents they could leave their air shelters, shortly after saying it had detected missiles launched from Iran.MAGA is divided over Trump’s decision to bomb Iran. Will it last?Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s decision to attack three nuclear sites in Iran this weekend has divided supporters and unsettled some allies of his “America First” movement who embraced his campaign-trail promises to “expel the warmongers from our government.”Republican leaders largely rallied behind the president after the strikes, but the notes of dissent were striking in a party usually in lockstep with Trump.This is an excerpt from a full story.How Trump got to ‘yes’ on bombing Iran Return to menuFor days, President Donald Trump played coy about his plans to strike Iran, declaring that he hadn’t yet made up his mind even as he approved attack plans and directed military officials to ready their forces.Within a small circle of White House and administration officials, it was clear that even when Trump announced Thursday that he might take as long as “two weeks” to decide, an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities was imminent, and the ruse was already underway.This is an excerpt from a full story.Trump suggests Iran regime change: ‘MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN’Return to menuHours after top Trump administration officials said Sunday that the United States didn’t want to change Iran’s regime, President Donald Trump appeared to suggest he’d be open to such a shuffle.“It’s not politically correct to use the term, ‘Regime Change,’ but if the current Iranian Regime is unable to MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN, why wouldn’t there be a Regime change???” Trump wrote on Truth Social. “MIGA!!!”Iran’s U.N. representative calls strike a ‘blatant crime’; Israel defends U.S. Return to menuAt an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council, Amir Saeid Iravani, Iran’s permanent representative to the U.N., painted the U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities as a “blatant crime” and accused Israel of drawing President Donald Trump into the conflict.IAEA leader: Violence could ‘reach unthinkable levels’ in Middle EastReturn to menuRafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, told the U.N. Security Council on Sunday that “violence and destruction could reach unthinkable levels” if peace doesn’t come to the Middle East soon.“The global nonproliferation regime, as we know it, could crumble,” Grossi said.Grossi condemned the U.S. military’s overnight strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities, saying those attacks “could result in radioactive releases with grave consequences.”Return to menuPresident Donald Trump described the damage from U.S. strikes on nuclear sites in Iran as “monumental,” in a post on Truth Social on Sunday, without offering specific details. “The hits were hard and accurate,” he added.What visuals show of damage to Iran’s nuclear sites after U.S. strike Return to menuSatellite imagery taken Sunday morning shows at least six apparent bomb entry points at Iran’s key Fordow uranium enrichment facility in Iran, according to a Washington Post visual analysis and multiple experts. The images are the first look at damage to one of Iran’s main nuclear facilities after American bombers struck that site and two others early Sunday local time.This is an excerpt from a full story.U.N. head calls strikes ‘a perilous turn’ as U.S. defends actions at Security Council meetingReturn to menuAs the U.N. Security Council began an emergency meeting Sunday afternoon, called by Iran to address the U.S. strikes on its nuclear program, Secretary General António Guterres recalled in his opening statement that he had urged in a meeting Friday, “Give peace a chance.”Return to menuIn a news briefing Sunday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin said Israel is “very close” to achieving its objectives, among which is eliminating Iran’s nuclear and ballistic missile threat. “We are committed to achieving our objectives. When those objectives are met, the operation will end and the fighting will stop,” Netanyahu said.Netanyahu also thanked President Donald Trump and the U.S. military for striking Iran’s key Fordow uranium enrichment facility, saying cooperation between the United States and Israel had reached an unprecedented peak.Return to menuIn a Sunday news briefing, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Effie Defrin said that Israel continues to strike Iran to “deepen the degradation” of the Iranian regime’s capabilities, including its weapons program and missile production industry. “However, the regime still retains capabilities. We saw that this morning,” he said.Fordow nuclear site ‘directly impacted,’ U.N. atomic watchdog reportsReturn to menuU.S. strikes “directly impacted” Iran’s Fordow fuel enrichment facility and left extensive damage at the Isfahan and Natanz facilities, the International Atomic Energy Agency said in a statement Sunday. “At this time, no one, including the IAEA, is in the position to assess the underground damage at Fordow,” IAEA Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi reported at an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council.Iranians brace for bigger conflict as Tehran weighs response to U.S. strikesReturn to menuA sweeping U.S. attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities has left many Iranians deeply worried about a widening conflict — as Tehran said it reserves “all options” to respond and accused Washington of scuttling diplomatic efforts.This is an excerpt from a full story.U.S. officials detail ‘limited attack’ in Iran bombing raidReturn to menuThe massive U.S. attack launched overnight on Iran’s nuclear program was unprecedented in its scope and the weaponry used, but it was intended as a limited strike and not to overthrow the Iranian government, top Trump administration officials said Sunday.“Our view has been very clear that we don’t want a regime change. … We want to end their nuclear program, and then we want to talk to the Iranians about a long-term settlement,” Vice President JD Vance said on NBC’s “Meet the Press.”This is an excerpt from a full story.U.S. embassies in region urge increased cautionReturn to menuU.S. embassies across the Middle East issued updated alerts to U.S. government personnel and American citizens on Sunday, urging them to maintain low profiles, increase caution and in some cases leave the country.The State Department on Sunday ordered Lebanon-based nonemergency U.S. government personnel and family members to leave the country “due to the volatile and unpredictable security situation in the region.”Democrats, some Republicans question Trump’s unilateral attack Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s decision to send U.S. forces to strike Iran without consulting Congress is prompting bipartisan unease among lawmakers, with most Democrats and a handful of Republicans questioning the accuracy of military intelligence behind the attack as well as the constitutionality of the president’s actions.This is an excerpt from a full story.Britain, France and Germany call on Iran to negotiate Return to menuThe leaders of Britain, France and Germany said Sunday that they were working to “defuse tensions” after the United States entered Israel’s war with Iran and bombed three Iranian nuclear facilities.But in a joint statement, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz came down hard on Iran, affirmed their countries’ support for Israel and said little about the U.S. strikes.Return to menuIsrael’s war cabinet was set to meet Sunday (starting at 8 p.m. local time, 1 p.m. Eastern time) to discuss the impact of U.S. strikes on Iran and the Israeli military’s ongoing operation there.Iran also requested an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council on Sunday, urging its members “to address this blatant and unlawful act of aggression, to condemn it in the strongest possible terms.” International Atomic Energy Agency Director General Rafael Grossi is scheduled to address the meeting at 3 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, the agency said on X.What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb?Return to menuThe signature weapons employed in the U.S. military’s predawn strike on Iran were 30,000-pound precision-guided “bunker busters” designed exclusively to destroy underground targets.U.S. strategic bombers dropped 14 of the munitions in the mission to degrade Iran’s nuclear program, top Pentagon officials said in a news conference Sunday. The GBU-57s, or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator (MOP for short), were carried by a fleet of B-2 bombers, the first time the munitions were used in combat.This is an excerpt from a full story.Kashmiri students being evacuated from Iran after U.S. strikesReturn to menuNEW DELHI — At least 110 students from the conflict-plagued region of Kashmir who are studying in Iran will evacuate the country Sunday, as the U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities escalate tensions in the region.The students at a medical university in Kerman, in south-central Iran, were to be taken to New Delhi on two flights from the northeastern city of Mashhad on Sunday, according to Nasir Khuehami, national convener of the Jammu and Kashmir Students Association.Attacks designed to degrade Iran’s ‘ambitions’ for nuclear weapons, Rubio saysReturn to menuSecretary of State Marco Rubio contended that President Donald Trump was justified in ordering military strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities even if he did not see evidence that Iran’s leader had ordered the country’s nuclear stockpile to be weaponized.Return to menuIranians who were injured in the U.S. strikes on nuclear sites were not affected by radiation contamination, Health Ministry spokesman Hossein Kermanpour said Sunday in a post on X.The strikes wounded 11 Iranians but did not cause any fatalities, the head of the Iranian Red Crescent society, Pirhossein Kolivand, told the Mehr news agency. It was not clear where the people were injured. The strikes targeted three of Iran’s nuclear facilities at Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan.Iran’s proxy forces express support, not action, in face of U.S. strikes on IranReturn to menuBEIRUT — Iran’s proxy forces in the Middle East issued statements of condemnation Sunday against the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear enrichment facilities, but largely stopped short of announcing they would join the conflict in retaliation.Reps. Khanna, Massie deliver bipartisan criticism of Trump’s actionsReturn to menuRep. Ro Khanna (D-California) framed President Donald Trump’s decision to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities as a strategic blunder that is deeply unpopular with Americans who are tired of foreign conflicts.Return to menuThe State Department ordered family members and nonemergency U.S. government personnel in Lebanon to leave due to the regional security situation, according to an alert from the U.S. Embassy in Beirut. The embassy also urged U.S. citizens to exercise caution and monitor breaking news.Return to menuRep. Thomas Massie (R-Kentucky), who has spoken out for weeks against any U.S. bombing of Iran, criticized the president for ordering a military strike against Iran’s nuclear facilities without consulting Congress first.“There was no imminent threat to the United States,” Massie said on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” before noting, “Congress was on vacation last week when all this was happening,” suggesting the lack of urgency to the bombing campaign.Return to menuIran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps warned Sunday that the United States should expect a response to its attacks on the country’s nuclear facilities, describing any retaliation as “legitimate self-defense.”“The bases and locations used by the forces that carried out the attacks have been identified,” the IRGC, Iran’s most powerful military and security force, said in a statement, calling the U.S. presence in the region “a point of weakness that increases the enemy’s vulnerability.”Tel Aviv buildings damaged by Iranian missile strikes Return to menuRescuers and authorities assessed damage to a northern Tel Aviv residential building, after it was hit in an Iranian attack early June 22. (Video: The Washington Post)TEL AVIV — Iran fired two volleys of ballistic missiles at targets across Israel on Sunday morning, penetrating air defenses, hitting residential buildings and wounding dozens of people, hours after the United States struck Iranian nuclear enrichment facilities.Large numbers of security and medical forces gathered in northern Tel Aviv on Sunday as residents whose homes were damaged by the strike packed suitcases and began evacuating — some still in their pajamas, stunned by the attack.Return to menuIsrael launched strikes at dozens of missile and drone sites across Iran on Sunday, the Israel Defense Forces said. The sites targeted in Yazd, Bushehr, Isfahan and Ahvaz included a strategic missile command center where long-range missiles are stored, and facilities used to produce aerial defense batteries, according to the IDF.Two sites were targeted in Bushehr — the home of Iran’s only commercial nuclear power plant — Ehsan Jahanian, a provincial official, told Iranian state media. Jahanian claimed that Iran’s defense network intercepted and destroyed “the hostile targets,” Tasnim News reported.Return to menuSecretary of State Marco Rubio contended that Iran had “everything you need to make a nuclear weapon,” including enough enriched uranium “to make at least nine or 10 bombs.”“They claim to have a space program. It’s not a space program. Iran’s not going to the moon,” he told Fox News’s “Sunday Morning Futures.” “They have a space program because they’re trying to develop ICBMs — long-range rockets that could one day reach the United States.”The U.S. “did the world a great favor” by bombing Iran’s nuclear facilities, he added.Return to menuPope Leo XIV called for peace in the Middle East, saying everyone “has a moral responsibility to stop the tragedy of war.”“There are no ‘distant’ conflicts when human dignity is at stake,” the pope said after a Sunday prayer on St. Peter’s Square in the Vatican.War doesn’t solve problems but “amplifies them and inflicts deep wounds on the history of peoples, which take generations to heal,” he said. “May diplomacy silence the weapons.”Escalation reignites fears for shipping in Strait of HormuzReturn to menuIranian lawmakers recommended Sunday that the government respond to U.S. strikes by closing the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic waterway and transit point for about 20 percent of the world’s oil.On Sunday, Tehran’s semiofficial Press TV reported that a foreign policy committee in parliament had recommended the Supreme National Security Council make the decision to close the strait, which forms the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf and separates Iran from the Arabian Peninsula.Return to menuSecretary of State Marco Rubio warned Iranian officials that “if they retaliate, it will be the worst mistake they’ve ever made.”“We can fly in and out of Iran at will,” Rubio said on Fox News’s “Sunday Morning Futures.”He said U.S. military forces went in, conducted the bombing and left, and “not a shot was fired against us. They didn’t even know what had happened. … The planes were out of their airspace before they finally started realizing they had been hit.”Return to menuSen. Mark Kelly (D-Arizona), a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said that, as far as lawmakers on the panel know, “the Iranians were not in the process of developing a weapon.”Kelly said he reviews intelligence daily and that it showed Iranians were enriching uranium but were working within the parameters laid down by the international community.“My big fear right now is that they take this entire program underground,” he said. “We don’t know what they’re going to do here in the future."Return to menuSecretary of State Marco Rubio said directly that the United States was not at war with Iran.“This is not a war against Iran,” Rubio said in an interview on Fox News Channel’s “Sunday Morning Futures.”The secretary added that President Donald Trump tried diplomacy first, asking Iran to shut down any nuclear weapon development and inviting leaders to negotiate. Rubio said Trump wanted to do this “peacefully.” Iranians, he said, “tried to play him.”“He handled it differently, but that was an Iranian choice. We didn’t make that choice. They did by playing games with Donald Trump,” he said.European leaders urge de-escalation and return to diplomacyReturn to menuEuropean leaders issued statements urging Tehran to exercise restraint as it decides on any response to Washington’s overnight strikes, calling on Iran to prioritize a diplomatic solution and reiterating their shared position that Iran should not have nuclear weapons.“Dialogue … is the only path that leads to peace and security for all,” French President Emmanuel Macron said Sunday, urging Iran to renounce its nuclear weapons and calling for a wider de-escalation.Return to menuSen. Tim Kaine (D-Virginia) said Sunday that it was “unconstitutional” for President Donald Trump to have attacked Iran without congressional authorization. “It was an offensive war of choice by a president without consultation of Congress,” he said on “Fox News Sunday.” “My state is a very pro-military state, and we’re deeply opposed to another war in the Middle East.”Return to menuSen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina), who has strongly supported President Donald Trump’s actions in Iran, told NBC News that he spoke to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday morning. Netanyahu, he said, wanted to thank the American people “for all we do for Israel.”“He wanted me to urge the Iranian people to end this madness, take this regime down,” Graham said. “He wanted me to tell the American people: Israel is not going to live this way anymore. They’re not going to live under threat from Iran anymore.”For Hegseth and Caine, a first news conference in a turbulent timeReturn to menuWhen Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, took to a Pentagon dais to detail the daring U.S. bombing raid on Iran’s nuclear sites, the image was rare in two regards: that it occurred early on a Sunday morning, and that either man was there at all.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump is still planning to attend this week’s NATO meeting at The Hague, a White House official confirmed, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss unannounced travel plans. He’s scheduled to leave Washington on Tuesday morning to attend the summit.Before B-2 strikes, U.S. submarine fired Tomahawk missiles into IranReturn to menuBefore B-2 Spirit bombers dropped bunker-busting munitions on Iranian nuclear sites, a U.S. submarine in the Middle East launched more than two dozen Tomahawk cruise missiles at “key infrastructure targets,” the Pentagon’s top general said. Those would seemingly have softened the battlefield ahead of the main strike.Video: Iranian news footage shows smoke rising from Fordow nuclear facilityReturn to menuVideo published by IRNA, the official news agency of Iran, on June 22 showed smoke rising from the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility. (Video: IRNA)A reporter for Iran’s state-run news agency shared a video Sunday showing what he said was smoke rising from the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility about 20 miles northeast of the city of Qom.President Donald Trump said U.S. warplanes carried out an attack on Fordow and two other nuclear sites early Sunday local time.Return to menuIsraeli President Isaac Herzog also told CNN on Sunday that Israel is “not dragging America into a war.” President Donald Trump decided to bomb Iran’s nuclear facilities, he said, because the nuclear program “was a clear and present danger to the security interests of all the free world, especially the leader of the free world.”“We are not intending, and we don’t ask, for America now to go to war because the Iranians are threatening Israel,” he said.U.S. forces in Middle East were not forewarned of strikes, officials sayReturn to menuThe 40,000 U.S. troops fanned out across the Middle East were not notified in advance of the strike in Iran, top Pentagon officials said Sunday, as military leaders keep them on “high alert” for any retaliatory attacks from Tehran or its proxies in the region.Return to menuIsraeli President Isaac Herzog told CNN on Sunday morning that he can’t say Iran’s nuclear program has been destroyed. “I can’t say it’s been eliminated,” he said. “I can say it’s been hit very hard, both by the Israeli attacks and, absolutely, by the American attack overnight. This is a very important development. It has major repercussions.”Return to menuSatellite imagery from Maxar Technologies shows damage at the Fordow fuel enrichment facility following U.S. strikes there early Sunday. At least two clusters of apparent bomb entry points are visible at the site. The imagery also shows gray-blue ash coating a wide area; also, tunnel entrances near where trucks were seen the day before appear to be filled with dirt.Return to menuVice President JD Vance, on NBC's “Meet The Press” on June 22, urged Iran not to retaliate, saying it would be “the stupidest thing.” (Video: NBC News)Vice President JD Vance warned Iran not to retaliate against U.S. troops, saying there’s an opportunity for a “reset” in relations.“The Iranians are clearly not very good at war,” Vance said Sunday on NBC News’s “Meet the Press.” “Perhaps they should follow President Trump’s lead and give peace a chance.”Return to menuVice President JD Vance said Sunday that President Donald Trump had the constitutional authority to strike Iran and claimed this was not the start of another “long, drawn-out” conflict in the Middle East.“I understand the concern,” Vance said on NBC News’s “Meet the Press.” “But the difference is, back then, we had dumb presidents, and now we have president who actually knows how to accomplish America’s national security objectives.”Return to menuAsked Sunday whether the Trump administration was prepared for an open-ended war after Sunday’s assault on Iran’s nuclear sites, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said, “This is most certainly not open-ended.” When pushed by another reporter about that possibility, Hegseth allowed, “Anything can happen in conflict,” before adding: “The scope of this was intentionally limited. That’s the message we’re sending.”Return to menuDefense Secretary Pete Hegseth told reporters Sunday that the administration is relaying public and private messages to Iranian authorities across multiple channels to give them “every opportunity to come to the table,” referring to diplomatic efforts. He added: “They understand precisely what the American position is and precisely what steps they can take to allow for peace.”Return to menuIn response to a question Sunday, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth asserted the Trump administration’s objective was not to depose the leadership in Tehran. “This mission was not, has not been about regime change,” Hegseth said. “The president authorized a precision operation to neutralize the threats to our national interest posed by the Iranian nuclear program,” he added.125 aircraft used in U.S. bombing of Iran, including decoy B-2sReturn to menuThe U.S. bombing of nuclear sites in Iran included more than 125 aircraft, missiles launched from a submarine and a decoy flight of B-2 stealth bombers that flew over the Pacific on Saturday to draw attention away from the mission, defense officials said Sunday.With fateful decision, Trump gambles his presidency on war Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s decision Saturday to strike Iran’s nuclear enrichment facilities was an extraordinary bet that he could eliminate a nuclear program that has bedeviled presidents while avoiding another long-running Middle East conflict of the sort he and his supporters have continually denounced. What happens next will have profound consequences for his presidency. If Iran is sufficiently weakened that it cannot meaningfully retaliate, Trump will have delivered a blow against a longtime adversary that will send a message to China, Russia and other global rivals that he will not shy from using military power when necessary. But if Iran does not agree to peace on Trump’s terms, the president’s promise that “there are many targets left” opened the door to a much deeper and potentially longer conflict. Already, that prospect is angering some members of his political base.This is an excerpt from a full story.Gulf countries that host U.S. bases make preparations for conflict to spreadReturn to menuBEIRUT — Bahrain and Kuwait, two Persian Gulf countries that host U.S. military bases, began making preparations Sunday for the possibility of the conflict between Israel and Iran spilling onto their soil following the U.S. attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities overnight.Return to menuFrench Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot said France did not take part in the execution or planning of U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities and urged “restraint in order to avoid any escalation.” Barrot added that France has “repeatedly expressed its firm opposition to Iran gaining access to nuclear weapons” and remains “convinced that a lasting solution to this issue requires a negotiated solution.”The U.S. ‘betrayed diplomacy,’ Iranian foreign minister saysReturn to menuIranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the United States’ overnight strikes against his country’s nuclear facilities in the “strongest terms” on Sunday, accusing Washington of cutting off diplomatic efforts and asserting that Iran reserved “all options” to act in self-defense.Return to menuIranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said he will travel to Moscow on Sunday for “serious consultations” with Russian President Vladimir Putin the following morning. “Russia is a friend of Iran, and we enjoy strategic partnership, and we always consult with each other and coordinate our positions,” he said at Sunday’s news briefing in Istanbul.Return to menuGermany’s government “received information immediately after the start of the airstrikes” on Iranian nuclear facilities, a German official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive information. Stefan Kornelius, a government spokesman, said in a Sunday statement that Berlin “assumes that large parts of Iran’s nuclear program were damaged by the airstrikes.” German Chancellor Friedrich Merz reiterated his call for Iran to immediately negotiate with the U.S. and Israel and to reach a diplomatic solution, Kornelius said.Middle East diplomats issue flurry of statements urging de-escalationReturn to menuDiplomats representing key U.S. allies in the Middle East urged Iran to exercise restraint and called for a negotiated settlement to the crisis Sunday morning, according to a statements issued by foreign ministries that expressed grave worry for regional and global security.Return to menuPeyman, 40, a computer engineer from Tehran, said people had started returning to the capital over the past two days after fleeing because of Israeli strikes. Their return appeared to be driven largely by economic concerns: “People cannot stay away and not earn any money for a long time,” especially those who made daily wages, said Peyman, who would be identified only by his first name for fear of government reprisal. “We are all just very confused.” People were feeling “a brief moment of excitement that this might be the beginning of a meaningful change, and in another [moment], the fear of complete chaos,” he said.Video shows blasts near Iran’s Isfahan nuclear technology center Return to menuSocial media video verified by geolocator Mitchell Ulrich on X and confirmed by The Post shows strikes in the direction of a nuclear facility in Isfahan, Iran. (Video: Social media, obtained by Reuters)Social media video posted on Sunday, which was verified by geolocator Mitchell Ulrich on X and later confirmed by The Washington Post, shows strikes in the direction of Iran’s nuclear technology center in Isfahan. In an address to the nation late Saturday night, President Donald Trump said the U.S. operation hit that facility as well as the heavily fortified Fordow plant and Iran’s main uranium enrichment site, Natanz.Following strikes on Iran, these U.S. bases could become targets Return to menuIn the days and weeks leading up to the U.S. attack on Iranian nuclear facilities, Iranian leaders had repeatedly warned of reprisal were a strike to occur. “All U.S. bases are within our reach and we will boldly target them,” Iranian Defense Minister Aziz Nasirzadeh said on June 11. Here are some of the U.S. bases and troop deployments in the region that could come under attack.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuA British cabinet minister said Sunday that the government was informed of the U.S. attack on Iran in advance but was not involved. “We are not and have not been involved in these attacks but … we are informed,” Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds said on Sky News. “I can’t tell you exactly when we did know, but we were informed, as you might expect, by a key ally of this action.” He said “no request was made” for Britain to back the strikes militarily.Return to menuLebanese President Joseph Aoun called for restraint following the U.S. strikes on Iran, amid concerns that Hezbollah could enter the fray. “Lebanon, its leadership, parties, and people, realize today, more than ever, that it has paid a heavy price for the wars that erupted on its soil and in the region,” he said in a statement Sunday on X. “It is unwilling to pay more, and there is no national interest in doing so, especially since the cost of these wars was and will be beyond its ability to bear.”Return to menuBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Washington had “taken action to alleviate” the threat of Iran developing a nuclear weapon and called on Tehran to “return to the negotiating table,” in a statement on X. On Friday, Britain’s foreign minister and three European counterparts pressed Iran’s top diplomat for curbs to Tehran’s nuclear program, but those talks failed to yield a quick off-ramp from the conflict.Iranians fear fallout of U.S. involvement in conflictReturn to menuIranians had for years imagined the possibility of an American attack on their country and saw it as a sort of “final stage of the game,” one businessman in Tehran said. “From a mental perspective, people feel that they’ve entered the final stage that they always feared,” he said.Return to menuRafael Mariano Grossi, head of the U.N. nuclear watchdog, said Sunday he’ll convene an emergency meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency’s board of governors “in light of the urgent situation in Iran.” The IAEA said earlier that “no increase in off-site radiation levels” was immediately reported in the aftermath of the U.S. strikes on three nuclear facilities.Return to menuIsraeli President Isaac Herzog thanked President Donald Trump after the United States conducted strikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities. “This critical operation serves the security interests of the entire free world,” Herzog wrote on X. “I hope it leads to a better future in the Middle East — and that it also helps bring about the urgent release of our hostages held in Gaza.”Israeli authorities announce restrictions for civiliansReturn to menuAuthorities in Israel have brought back restrictions for civilians after the United States announced that it had struck three nuclear facilities in Iran, marking a major escalation in the conflict and setting the region on edge. Workplaces and schools will remain closed, the Home Front Command of the Israel Defense Forces announced in a statement, with all activities limited to essential services until Monday morning. The Israel Airports Authority also announced that Israeli airspace was closed.Return to menuIran’s United Nations mission demanded an emergency meeting at the U.N. Security Council “without delay” to address the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities, in a letter addressed to U.N. Secretary General António Guterres and the council’s chair. Iran condemned the strikes and said Washington must be held fully accountable.Satellite imagery shows truck activity at nuclear site before strikeReturn to menuIn the two days before the United States carried out strikes on three Iranian nuclear facilities, satellite imagery shows “unusual truck and vehicular activity” at the Fordow fuel enrichment facility, according to a senior analyst at the satellite firm Maxar.Return to menuYemen’s Houthis condemned the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities, calling the operation “a dangerous escalation and a direct threat to regional and international security and peace.” Before the strikes, the militant group said in a statement that it would target American ships in the Red Sea if “the U.S. gets involved in an attack and aggression against Iran.”Return to menuIran’s National Center for Nuclear Safety said no signs of contamination were detected after it conducted inspections in areas surrounding the nuclear facilities hit in U.S. strikes, according to Iran’s semiofficial Mehr News Agency. The International Atomic Energy Agency said on X that “no increase in off-site radiation levels” had been reported from the three sites.Members of Congress react to Trump’s strikes on IranReturn to menuSeveral members of Congress on both sides of the aisle criticized the Trump administration for carrying out strikes on Iran without congressional authorization.Only Congress can declare war on a foreign nation, according to Article I Section 8, Clause 11 of the Constitution, although the president controls the armed forces and is commander in chief.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces said it had detected a second wave of missiles fired from Iran. Air defense systems are “identifying and intercepting threats,” it said. The IDF later issued the all-clear for “several areas,” adding that search and rescue forces are operating in locations where there were reports of fallen projectiles.Fires, casualties after Iranian missile strike on IsraelReturn to menuA wave of missiles from Iran wounded 16 people and directly hit residential buildings in central Israel, sparking fires, according to Israeli authorities.Firefighters are searching for people who could be trapped at two primary impact sites in the Central and Dan districts, according to Israel’s Fire and Rescue Services. Fires that broke out in these areas have been extinguished, it added.Iran’s atomic agency condemns U.S. strike, vows to continue nuclear programReturn to menuIran’s Atomic Energy Organization on Sunday described the U.S. strikes on nuclear sites in Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan as an act of “lawlessness based on the rules of the jungle” in a defiant statement that vowed the Iranian nuclear program would continue.These are the three Iranian nuclear sites targeted by the U.S.Return to menuU.S. warplanes strike three Iranian nuclear sites in sweeping attackReturn to menuThe U.S. military carried out sweeping strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities, President Donald Trump said late Saturday, marking a major escalation for his administration that tethers the United States directly to a conflict with no clear outcome or end in sight.This is an excerpt from a full story.Strikes on Iran involved B-2 bombers, fighter jets and numerous ‘bunker busters,’ U.S. official saysReturn to menuA U.S. official familiar with the American military operation in Iran said it included B-2 bombers, as widely anticipated, but also other aircraft such as fighter jets. Numerous 30,000-pound, bunker-busting bombs known in the Air Force as Massive Ordnance Penetrators were dropped, the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue.
html:
President Donald Trump suggested the possibility of regime change in Iran, after his top officials said the administration wasn’t interested in such a move. On social media, he posted that “if the current Iranian Regime is unable to MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN, why wouldn’t there be a Regime change?” The U.N. Security Council held an emergency meeting called by Iran to address the U.S. strikes on its nuclear facilities. International Atomic Energy Agency officials are still assessing the extent of the damage. Iran’s permanent representative to the United Nations described the U.S. strikes as a “blatant crime” and accused Israel of drawing Trump into the conflict, adding that Iran’s armed forces will decide the “timing, nature, and scale of Iran’s proportionate response.”

What else to know after the U.S. attacks

Return to menu

  • President Donald Trump said U.S. warplanes carried out a “very successful attack” on three Iranian sites, including the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility, which is hundreds of feet below ground. He did not cite evidence regarding the strikes’ impact. All three facilities sustained “extremely severe damage and destruction,” said Chairman of the Joints Chief of Staff Dan Caine, citing initial damage assessments. Israeli military spokesman Effie Defrin said Sunday that the strikes were carried out in full coordination with the Israel Defense Forces, without giving any further details.
  • Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities in the “strongest terms” on Sunday, accusing Washington of betraying diplomatic efforts and asserting that Iran reserved “all options” to act in self-defense.
  • Israel and Iran traded fire for a 10th day Sunday as the Israeli defense minister said the country’s military “will continue operations until the objectives of the operation are achieved.” Iranian missiles penetrated Israeli air defenses and struck buildings in central Israel during two volleys of attacks, the IDF said. Iranian state media reported deaths and injuries from Israeli airstrikes on Iran on Sunday, while the IDF said it struck military targets in multiple regions across Iran.

Live coverage contributors 43

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces gave the all-clear, telling residents they could leave their air shelters, shortly after saying it had detected missiles launched from Iran.

  • MAGA is divided over Trump’s decision to bomb Iran. Will it last?

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump’s decision to attack three nuclear sites in Iran this weekend has divided supporters and unsettled some allies of his “America First” movement who embraced his campaign-trail promises to “expel the warmongers from our government.”

    Republican leaders largely rallied behind the president after the strikes, but the notes of dissent were striking in a party usually in lockstep with Trump.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • How Trump got to ‘yes’ on bombing Iran

    Return to menu

    For days, President Donald Trump played coy about his plans to strike Iran, declaring that he hadn’t yet made up his mind even as he approved attack plans and directed military officials to ready their forces.

    Within a small circle of White House and administration officials, it was clear that even when Trump announced Thursday that he might take as long as “two weeks” to decide, an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities was imminent, and the ruse was already underway.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Trump suggests Iran regime change: ‘MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN’

    Return to menu

    Hours after top Trump administration officials said Sunday that the United States didn’t want to change Iran’s regime, President Donald Trump appeared to suggest he’d be open to such a shuffle.

    “It’s not politically correct to use the term, ‘Regime Change,’ but if the current Iranian Regime is unable to MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN, why wouldn’t there be a Regime change???” Trump wrote on Truth Social. “MIGA!!!”

  • Iran’s U.N. representative calls strike a ‘blatant crime’; Israel defends U.S.

    Return to menu

    At an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council, Amir Saeid Iravani, Iran’s permanent representative to the U.N., painted the U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities as a “blatant crime” and accused Israel of drawing President Donald Trump into the conflict.

  • IAEA leader: Violence could ‘reach unthinkable levels’ in Middle East

    Return to menu

    Rafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, told the U.N. Security Council on Sunday that “violence and destruction could reach unthinkable levels” if peace doesn’t come to the Middle East soon.

    “The global nonproliferation regime, as we know it, could crumble,” Grossi said.

    Grossi condemned the U.S. military’s overnight strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities, saying those attacks “could result in radioactive releases with grave consequences.”

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump described the damage from U.S. strikes on nuclear sites in Iran as “monumental,” in a post on Truth Social on Sunday, without offering specific details. “The hits were hard and accurate,” he added.

  • What visuals show of damage to Iran’s nuclear sites after U.S. strike

    Return to menu

    Satellite imagery taken Sunday morning shows at least six apparent bomb entry points at Iran’s key Fordow uranium enrichment facility in Iran, according to a Washington Post visual analysis and multiple experts. The images are the first look at damage to one of Iran’s main nuclear facilities after American bombers struck that site and two others early Sunday local time.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • U.N. head calls strikes ‘a perilous turn’ as U.S. defends actions at Security Council meeting

    Return to menu

    As the U.N. Security Council began an emergency meeting Sunday afternoon, called by Iran to address the U.S. strikes on its nuclear program, Secretary General António Guterres recalled in his opening statement that he had urged in a meeting Friday, “Give peace a chance.”

  • Return to menu

    In a news briefing Sunday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin said Israel is “very close” to achieving its objectives, among which is eliminating Iran’s nuclear and ballistic missile threat. “We are committed to achieving our objectives. When those objectives are met, the operation will end and the fighting will stop,” Netanyahu said.

    Netanyahu also thanked President Donald Trump and the U.S. military for striking Iran’s key Fordow uranium enrichment facility, saying cooperation between the United States and Israel had reached an unprecedented peak.

  • Return to menu

    In a Sunday news briefing, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Effie Defrin said that Israel continues to strike Iran to “deepen the degradation” of the Iranian regime’s capabilities, including its weapons program and missile production industry. “However, the regime still retains capabilities. We saw that this morning,” he said.

  • Fordow nuclear site ‘directly impacted,’ U.N. atomic watchdog reports

    Return to menu

    U.S. strikes “directly impacted” Iran’s Fordow fuel enrichment facility and left extensive damage at the Isfahan and Natanz facilities, the International Atomic Energy Agency said in a statement Sunday. “At this time, no one, including the IAEA, is in the position to assess the underground damage at Fordow,” IAEA Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi reported at an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council.

  • Iranians brace for bigger conflict as Tehran weighs response to U.S. strikes

    Return to menu

    A sweeping U.S. attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities has left many Iranians deeply worried about a widening conflict — as Tehran said it reserves “all options” to respond and accused Washington of scuttling diplomatic efforts.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • U.S. officials detail ‘limited attack’ in Iran bombing raid

    Return to menu

    The massive U.S. attack launched overnight on Iran’s nuclear program was unprecedented in its scope and the weaponry used, but it was intended as a limited strike and not to overthrow the Iranian government, top Trump administration officials said Sunday.

    “Our view has been very clear that we don’t want a regime change. … We want to end their nuclear program, and then we want to talk to the Iranians about a long-term settlement,” Vice President JD Vance said on NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • U.S. embassies in region urge increased caution

    Return to menu

    U.S. embassies across the Middle East issued updated alerts to U.S. government personnel and American citizens on Sunday, urging them to maintain low profiles, increase caution and in some cases leave the country.

    The State Department on Sunday ordered Lebanon-based nonemergency U.S. government personnel and family members to leave the country “due to the volatile and unpredictable security situation in the region.”

  • Democrats, some Republicans question Trump’s unilateral attack

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump’s decision to send U.S. forces to strike Iran without consulting Congress is prompting bipartisan unease among lawmakers, with most Democrats and a handful of Republicans questioning the accuracy of military intelligence behind the attack as well as the constitutionality of the president’s actions.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Britain, France and Germany call on Iran to negotiate

    Return to menu

    The leaders of Britain, France and Germany said Sunday that they were working to “defuse tensions” after the United States entered Israel’s war with Iran and bombed three Iranian nuclear facilities.

    But in a joint statement, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz came down hard on Iran, affirmed their countries’ support for Israel and said little about the U.S. strikes.

  • Return to menu

    Israel’s war cabinet was set to meet Sunday (starting at 8 p.m. local time, 1 p.m. Eastern time) to discuss the impact of U.S. strikes on Iran and the Israeli military’s ongoing operation there.

    Iran also requested an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council on Sunday, urging its members “to address this blatant and unlawful act of aggression, to condemn it in the strongest possible terms.” International Atomic Energy Agency Director General Rafael Grossi is scheduled to address the meeting at 3 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, the agency said on X.

  • What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb?

    Return to menu

    The signature weapons employed in the U.S. military’s predawn strike on Iran were 30,000-pound precision-guided “bunker busters” designed exclusively to destroy underground targets.

    U.S. strategic bombers dropped 14 of the munitions in the mission to degrade Iran’s nuclear program, top Pentagon officials said in a news conference Sunday. The GBU-57s, or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator (MOP for short), were carried by a fleet of B-2 bombers, the first time the munitions were used in combat.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Kashmiri students being evacuated from Iran after U.S. strikes

    Return to menu

    NEW DELHI — At least 110 students from the conflict-plagued region of Kashmir who are studying in Iran will evacuate the country Sunday, as the U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities escalate tensions in the region.

    The students at a medical university in Kerman, in south-central Iran, were to be taken to New Delhi on two flights from the northeastern city of Mashhad on Sunday, according to Nasir Khuehami, national convener of the Jammu and Kashmir Students Association.

  • Attacks designed to degrade Iran’s ‘ambitions’ for nuclear weapons, Rubio says

    Return to menu

    Secretary of State Marco Rubio contended that President Donald Trump was justified in ordering military strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities even if he did not see evidence that Iran’s leader had ordered the country’s nuclear stockpile to be weaponized.

  • Return to menu

    Iranians who were injured in the U.S. strikes on nuclear sites were not affected by radiation contamination, Health Ministry spokesman Hossein Kermanpour said Sunday in a post on X.

    The strikes wounded 11 Iranians but did not cause any fatalities, the head of the Iranian Red Crescent society, Pirhossein Kolivand, told the Mehr news agency. It was not clear where the people were injured. The strikes targeted three of Iran’s nuclear facilities at Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan.

  • Iran’s proxy forces express support, not action, in face of U.S. strikes on Iran

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — Iran’s proxy forces in the Middle East issued statements of condemnation Sunday against the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear enrichment facilities, but largely stopped short of announcing they would join the conflict in retaliation.

  • Reps. Khanna, Massie deliver bipartisan criticism of Trump’s actions

    Return to menu

    Rep. Ro Khanna (D-California) framed President Donald Trump’s decision to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities as a strategic blunder that is deeply unpopular with Americans who are tired of foreign conflicts.

  • Return to menu

    The State Department ordered family members and nonemergency U.S. government personnel in Lebanon to leave due to the regional security situation, according to an alert from the U.S. Embassy in Beirut. The embassy also urged U.S. citizens to exercise caution and monitor breaking news.

  • Return to menu

    Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Kentucky), who has spoken out for weeks against any U.S. bombing of Iran, criticized the president for ordering a military strike against Iran’s nuclear facilities without consulting Congress first.

    “There was no imminent threat to the United States,” Massie said on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” before noting, “Congress was on vacation last week when all this was happening,” suggesting the lack of urgency to the bombing campaign.

  • Return to menu

    Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps warned Sunday that the United States should expect a response to its attacks on the country’s nuclear facilities, describing any retaliation as “legitimate self-defense.”

    “The bases and locations used by the forces that carried out the attacks have been identified,” the IRGC, Iran’s most powerful military and security force, said in a statement, calling the U.S. presence in the region “a point of weakness that increases the enemy’s vulnerability.”

  • Tel Aviv buildings damaged by Iranian missile strikes

    Return to menu

    TEL AVIV — Iran fired two volleys of ballistic missiles at targets across Israel on Sunday morning, penetrating air defenses, hitting residential buildings and wounding dozens of people, hours after the United States struck Iranian nuclear enrichment facilities.

    Large numbers of security and medical forces gathered in northern Tel Aviv on Sunday as residents whose homes were damaged by the strike packed suitcases and began evacuating — some still in their pajamas, stunned by the attack.

  • Return to menu

    Israel launched strikes at dozens of missile and drone sites across Iran on Sunday, the Israel Defense Forces said. The sites targeted in Yazd, Bushehr, Isfahan and Ahvaz included a strategic missile command center where long-range missiles are stored, and facilities used to produce aerial defense batteries, according to the IDF.

    Two sites were targeted in Bushehr — the home of Iran’s only commercial nuclear power plant — Ehsan Jahanian, a provincial official, told Iranian state media. Jahanian claimed that Iran’s defense network intercepted and destroyed “the hostile targets,” Tasnim News reported.

  • Return to menu

    Secretary of State Marco Rubio contended that Iran had “everything you need to make a nuclear weapon,” including enough enriched uranium “to make at least nine or 10 bombs.”

    “They claim to have a space program. It’s not a space program. Iran’s not going to the moon,” he told Fox News’s “Sunday Morning Futures.” “They have a space program because they’re trying to develop ICBMs — long-range rockets that could one day reach the United States.”

    The U.S. “did the world a great favor” by bombing Iran’s nuclear facilities, he added.

  • Return to menu

    Pope Leo XIV called for peace in the Middle East, saying everyone “has a moral responsibility to stop the tragedy of war.”

    “There are no ‘distant’ conflicts when human dignity is at stake,” the pope said after a Sunday prayer on St. Peter’s Square in the Vatican.

    War doesn’t solve problems but “amplifies them and inflicts deep wounds on the history of peoples, which take generations to heal,” he said. “May diplomacy silence the weapons.”

  • Escalation reignites fears for shipping in Strait of Hormuz

    Return to menu

    Iranian lawmakers recommended Sunday that the government respond to U.S. strikes by closing the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic waterway and transit point for about 20 percent of the world’s oil.

    On Sunday, Tehran’s semiofficial Press TV reported that a foreign policy committee in parliament had recommended the Supreme National Security Council make the decision to close the strait, which forms the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf and separates Iran from the Arabian Peninsula.

  • Return to menu

    Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned Iranian officials that “if they retaliate, it will be the worst mistake they’ve ever made.”

    “We can fly in and out of Iran at will,” Rubio said on Fox News’s “Sunday Morning Futures.”

    He said U.S. military forces went in, conducted the bombing and left, and “not a shot was fired against us. They didn’t even know what had happened. … The planes were out of their airspace before they finally started realizing they had been hit.”

  • Return to menu

    Sen. Mark Kelly (D-Arizona), a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said that, as far as lawmakers on the panel know, “the Iranians were not in the process of developing a weapon.”

    Kelly said he reviews intelligence daily and that it showed Iranians were enriching uranium but were working within the parameters laid down by the international community.

    “My big fear right now is that they take this entire program underground,” he said. “We don’t know what they’re going to do here in the future."

  • Return to menu

    Secretary of State Marco Rubio said directly that the United States was not at war with Iran.

    “This is not a war against Iran,” Rubio said in an interview on Fox News Channel’s “Sunday Morning Futures.”

    The secretary added that President Donald Trump tried diplomacy first, asking Iran to shut down any nuclear weapon development and inviting leaders to negotiate. Rubio said Trump wanted to do this “peacefully.” Iranians, he said, “tried to play him.”

    “He handled it differently, but that was an Iranian choice. We didn’t make that choice. They did by playing games with Donald Trump,” he said.

  • European leaders urge de-escalation and return to diplomacy

    Return to menu

    European leaders issued statements urging Tehran to exercise restraint as it decides on any response to Washington’s overnight strikes, calling on Iran to prioritize a diplomatic solution and reiterating their shared position that Iran should not have nuclear weapons.

    “Dialogue … is the only path that leads to peace and security for all,” French President Emmanuel Macron said Sunday, urging Iran to renounce its nuclear weapons and calling for a wider de-escalation.

  • Return to menu

    Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Virginia) said Sunday that it was “unconstitutional” for President Donald Trump to have attacked Iran without congressional authorization. “It was an offensive war of choice by a president without consultation of Congress,” he said on “Fox News Sunday.” “My state is a very pro-military state, and we’re deeply opposed to another war in the Middle East.”

  • Return to menu

    Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina), who has strongly supported President Donald Trump’s actions in Iran, told NBC News that he spoke to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday morning. Netanyahu, he said, wanted to thank the American people “for all we do for Israel.”

    “He wanted me to urge the Iranian people to end this madness, take this regime down,” Graham said. “He wanted me to tell the American people: Israel is not going to live this way anymore. They’re not going to live under threat from Iran anymore.”

  • For Hegseth and Caine, a first news conference in a turbulent time

    Return to menu

    When Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, took to a Pentagon dais to detail the daring U.S. bombing raid on Iran’s nuclear sites, the image was rare in two regards: that it occurred early on a Sunday morning, and that either man was there at all.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump is still planning to attend this week’s NATO meeting at The Hague, a White House official confirmed, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss unannounced travel plans. He’s scheduled to leave Washington on Tuesday morning to attend the summit.

  • Before B-2 strikes, U.S. submarine fired Tomahawk missiles into Iran

    Return to menu

    Before B-2 Spirit bombers dropped bunker-busting munitions on Iranian nuclear sites, a U.S. submarine in the Middle East launched more than two dozen Tomahawk cruise missiles at “key infrastructure targets,” the Pentagon’s top general said. Those would seemingly have softened the battlefield ahead of the main strike.

  • Video: Iranian news footage shows smoke rising from Fordow nuclear facility

    Return to menu

    A reporter for Iran’s state-run news agency shared a video Sunday showing what he said was smoke rising from the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility about 20 miles northeast of the city of Qom.

    President Donald Trump said U.S. warplanes carried out an attack on Fordow and two other nuclear sites early Sunday local time.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli President Isaac Herzog also told CNN on Sunday that Israel is “not dragging America into a war.” President Donald Trump decided to bomb Iran’s nuclear facilities, he said, because the nuclear program “was a clear and present danger to the security interests of all the free world, especially the leader of the free world.”

    “We are not intending, and we don’t ask, for America now to go to war because the Iranians are threatening Israel,” he said.

  • U.S. forces in Middle East were not forewarned of strikes, officials say

    Return to menu

    The 40,000 U.S. troops fanned out across the Middle East were not notified in advance of the strike in Iran, top Pentagon officials said Sunday, as military leaders keep them on “high alert” for any retaliatory attacks from Tehran or its proxies in the region.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli President Isaac Herzog told CNN on Sunday morning that he can’t say Iran’s nuclear program has been destroyed. “I can’t say it’s been eliminated,” he said. “I can say it’s been hit very hard, both by the Israeli attacks and, absolutely, by the American attack overnight. This is a very important development. It has major repercussions.”

  • Return to menu

    Satellite imagery from Maxar Technologies shows damage at the Fordow fuel enrichment facility following U.S. strikes there early Sunday. At least two clusters of apparent bomb entry points are visible at the site. The imagery also shows gray-blue ash coating a wide area; also, tunnel entrances near where trucks were seen the day before appear to be filled with dirt.

  • Return to menu

    Vice President JD Vance warned Iran not to retaliate against U.S. troops, saying there’s an opportunity for a “reset” in relations.

    “The Iranians are clearly not very good at war,” Vance said Sunday on NBC News’s “Meet the Press.” “Perhaps they should follow President Trump’s lead and give peace a chance.”

  • Return to menu

    Vice President JD Vance said Sunday that President Donald Trump had the constitutional authority to strike Iran and claimed this was not the start of another “long, drawn-out” conflict in the Middle East.

    “I understand the concern,” Vance said on NBC News’s “Meet the Press.” “But the difference is, back then, we had dumb presidents, and now we have president who actually knows how to accomplish America’s national security objectives.”

  • Return to menu

    Asked Sunday whether the Trump administration was prepared for an open-ended war after Sunday’s assault on Iran’s nuclear sites, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said, “This is most certainly not open-ended.” When pushed by another reporter about that possibility, Hegseth allowed, “Anything can happen in conflict,” before adding: “The scope of this was intentionally limited. That’s the message we’re sending.”

  • Return to menu

    Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth told reporters Sunday that the administration is relaying public and private messages to Iranian authorities across multiple channels to give them “every opportunity to come to the table,” referring to diplomatic efforts. He added: “They understand precisely what the American position is and precisely what steps they can take to allow for peace.”

  • Return to menu

    In response to a question Sunday, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth asserted the Trump administration’s objective was not to depose the leadership in Tehran. “This mission was not, has not been about regime change,” Hegseth said. “The president authorized a precision operation to neutralize the threats to our national interest posed by the Iranian nuclear program,” he added.

  • 125 aircraft used in U.S. bombing of Iran, including decoy B-2s

    Return to menu

    The U.S. bombing of nuclear sites in Iran included more than 125 aircraft, missiles launched from a submarine and a decoy flight of B-2 stealth bombers that flew over the Pacific on Saturday to draw attention away from the mission, defense officials said Sunday.

  • With fateful decision, Trump gambles his presidency on war

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump’s decision Saturday to strike Iran’s nuclear enrichment facilities was an extraordinary bet that he could eliminate a nuclear program that has bedeviled presidents while avoiding another long-running Middle East conflict of the sort he and his supporters have continually denounced. What happens next will have profound consequences for his presidency. If Iran is sufficiently weakened that it cannot meaningfully retaliate, Trump will have delivered a blow against a longtime adversary that will send a message to China, Russia and other global rivals that he will not shy from using military power when necessary. But if Iran does not agree to peace on Trump’s terms, the president’s promise that “there are many targets left” opened the door to a much deeper and potentially longer conflict. Already, that prospect is angering some members of his political base.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Gulf countries that host U.S. bases make preparations for conflict to spread

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — Bahrain and Kuwait, two Persian Gulf countries that host U.S. military bases, began making preparations Sunday for the possibility of the conflict between Israel and Iran spilling onto their soil following the U.S. attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities overnight.

  • Return to menu

    French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot said France did not take part in the execution or planning of U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities and urged “restraint in order to avoid any escalation.” Barrot added that France has “repeatedly expressed its firm opposition to Iran gaining access to nuclear weapons” and remains “convinced that a lasting solution to this issue requires a negotiated solution.”

  • The U.S. ‘betrayed diplomacy,’ Iranian foreign minister says

    Return to menu

    Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the United States’ overnight strikes against his country’s nuclear facilities in the “strongest terms” on Sunday, accusing Washington of cutting off diplomatic efforts and asserting that Iran reserved “all options” to act in self-defense.

  • Return to menu

    Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said he will travel to Moscow on Sunday for “serious consultations” with Russian President Vladimir Putin the following morning. “Russia is a friend of Iran, and we enjoy strategic partnership, and we always consult with each other and coordinate our positions,” he said at Sunday’s news briefing in Istanbul.

  • Return to menu

    Germany’s government “received information immediately after the start of the airstrikes” on Iranian nuclear facilities, a German official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive information. Stefan Kornelius, a government spokesman, said in a Sunday statement that Berlin “assumes that large parts of Iran’s nuclear program were damaged by the airstrikes.” German Chancellor Friedrich Merz reiterated his call for Iran to immediately negotiate with the U.S. and Israel and to reach a diplomatic solution, Kornelius said.

  • Middle East diplomats issue flurry of statements urging de-escalation

    Return to menu

    Diplomats representing key U.S. allies in the Middle East urged Iran to exercise restraint and called for a negotiated settlement to the crisis Sunday morning, according to a statements issued by foreign ministries that expressed grave worry for regional and global security.

  • Return to menu

    Peyman, 40, a computer engineer from Tehran, said people had started returning to the capital over the past two days after fleeing because of Israeli strikes. Their return appeared to be driven largely by economic concerns: “People cannot stay away and not earn any money for a long time,” especially those who made daily wages, said Peyman, who would be identified only by his first name for fear of government reprisal. “We are all just very confused.” People were feeling “a brief moment of excitement that this might be the beginning of a meaningful change, and in another [moment], the fear of complete chaos,” he said.

  • Video shows blasts near Iran’s Isfahan nuclear technology center

    Return to menu

    Social media video posted on Sunday, which was verified by geolocator Mitchell Ulrich on X and later confirmed by The Washington Post, shows strikes in the direction of Iran’s nuclear technology center in Isfahan. In an address to the nation late Saturday night, President Donald Trump said the U.S. operation hit that facility as well as the heavily fortified Fordow plant and Iran’s main uranium enrichment site, Natanz.

  • Following strikes on Iran, these U.S. bases could become targets

    Return to menu

    In the days and weeks leading up to the U.S. attack on Iranian nuclear facilities, Iranian leaders had repeatedly warned of reprisal were a strike to occur. “All U.S. bases are within our reach and we will boldly target them,” Iranian Defense Minister Aziz Nasirzadeh said on June 11. Here are some of the U.S. bases and troop deployments in the region that could come under attack.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    A British cabinet minister said Sunday that the government was informed of the U.S. attack on Iran in advance but was not involved. “We are not and have not been involved in these attacks but … we are informed,” Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds said on Sky News. “I can’t tell you exactly when we did know, but we were informed, as you might expect, by a key ally of this action.” He said “no request was made” for Britain to back the strikes militarily.

  • Return to menu

    Lebanese President Joseph Aoun called for restraint following the U.S. strikes on Iran, amid concerns that Hezbollah could enter the fray. “Lebanon, its leadership, parties, and people, realize today, more than ever, that it has paid a heavy price for the wars that erupted on its soil and in the region,” he said in a statement Sunday on X. “It is unwilling to pay more, and there is no national interest in doing so, especially since the cost of these wars was and will be beyond its ability to bear.”

  • Return to menu

    British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Washington had “taken action to alleviate” the threat of Iran developing a nuclear weapon and called on Tehran to “return to the negotiating table,” in a statement on X. On Friday, Britain’s foreign minister and three European counterparts pressed Iran’s top diplomat for curbs to Tehran’s nuclear program, but those talks failed to yield a quick off-ramp from the conflict.

  • Iranians fear fallout of U.S. involvement in conflict

    Return to menu

    Iranians had for years imagined the possibility of an American attack on their country and saw it as a sort of “final stage of the game,” one businessman in Tehran said. “From a mental perspective, people feel that they’ve entered the final stage that they always feared,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    Rafael Mariano Grossi, head of the U.N. nuclear watchdog, said Sunday he’ll convene an emergency meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency’s board of governors “in light of the urgent situation in Iran.” The IAEA said earlier that “no increase in off-site radiation levels” was immediately reported in the aftermath of the U.S. strikes on three nuclear facilities.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli President Isaac Herzog thanked President Donald Trump after the United States conducted strikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities. “This critical operation serves the security interests of the entire free world,” Herzog wrote on X. “I hope it leads to a better future in the Middle East — and that it also helps bring about the urgent release of our hostages held in Gaza.”

  • Israeli authorities announce restrictions for civilians

    Return to menu

    Authorities in Israel have brought back restrictions for civilians after the United States announced that it had struck three nuclear facilities in Iran, marking a major escalation in the conflict and setting the region on edge. Workplaces and schools will remain closed, the Home Front Command of the Israel Defense Forces announced in a statement, with all activities limited to essential services until Monday morning. The Israel Airports Authority also announced that Israeli airspace was closed.

  • Return to menu

    Iran’s United Nations mission demanded an emergency meeting at the U.N. Security Council “without delay” to address the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities, in a letter addressed to U.N. Secretary General António Guterres and the council’s chair. Iran condemned the strikes and said Washington must be held fully accountable.

  • Satellite imagery shows truck activity at nuclear site before strike

    Return to menu

    In the two days before the United States carried out strikes on three Iranian nuclear facilities, satellite imagery shows “unusual truck and vehicular activity” at the Fordow fuel enrichment facility, according to a senior analyst at the satellite firm Maxar.

  • Return to menu

    Yemen’s Houthis condemned the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities, calling the operation “a dangerous escalation and a direct threat to regional and international security and peace.” Before the strikes, the militant group said in a statement that it would target American ships in the Red Sea if “the U.S. gets involved in an attack and aggression against Iran.”

  • Return to menu

    Iran’s National Center for Nuclear Safety said no signs of contamination were detected after it conducted inspections in areas surrounding the nuclear facilities hit in U.S. strikes, according to Iran’s semiofficial Mehr News Agency. The International Atomic Energy Agency said on X that “no increase in off-site radiation levels” had been reported from the three sites.

  • Members of Congress react to Trump’s strikes on Iran

    Return to menu

    Several members of Congress on both sides of the aisle criticized the Trump administration for carrying out strikes on Iran without congressional authorization.

    Only Congress can declare war on a foreign nation, according to Article I Section 8, Clause 11 of the Constitution, although the president controls the armed forces and is commander in chief.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces said it had detected a second wave of missiles fired from Iran. Air defense systems are “identifying and intercepting threats,” it said. The IDF later issued the all-clear for “several areas,” adding that search and rescue forces are operating in locations where there were reports of fallen projectiles.

  • Fires, casualties after Iranian missile strike on Israel

    Return to menu

    A wave of missiles from Iran wounded 16 people and directly hit residential buildings in central Israel, sparking fires, according to Israeli authorities.

    Firefighters are searching for people who could be trapped at two primary impact sites in the Central and Dan districts, according to Israel’s Fire and Rescue Services. Fires that broke out in these areas have been extinguished, it added.

  • Iran’s atomic agency condemns U.S. strike, vows to continue nuclear program

    Return to menu

    Iran’s Atomic Energy Organization on Sunday described the U.S. strikes on nuclear sites in Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan as an act of “lawlessness based on the rules of the jungle” in a defiant statement that vowed the Iranian nuclear program would continue.

  • These are the three Iranian nuclear sites targeted by the U.S.

  • U.S. warplanes strike three Iranian nuclear sites in sweeping attack

    Return to menu

    The U.S. military carried out sweeping strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities, President Donald Trump said late Saturday, marking a major escalation for his administration that tethers the United States directly to a conflict with no clear outcome or end in sight.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Strikes on Iran involved B-2 bombers, fighter jets and numerous ‘bunker busters,’ U.S. official says

    Return to menu

    A U.S. official familiar with the American military operation in Iran said it included B-2 bombers, as widely anticipated, but also other aircraft such as fighter jets. Numerous 30,000-pound, bunker-busting bombs known in the Air Force as Massive Ordnance Penetrators were dropped, the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue.
